before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"29hei","text":"Please note that protocols with Q5® Hot Start High-Fidelity DNA Polymerase may differ from protocols with other polymerases. Conditions recommended below should be used for optimal performance.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"6ag1n","text":"Q5®Hot Start High-Fidelity DNA Polymerase is a high-fidelity, thermostable, hot start DNA polymerase with 3´→ 5´ exonuclease activity, fused to a processivity-enhancing Sso7d domain to support robust DNA amplification. The addition of an aptamer-based inhibitor allows room temperature reaction setup. With an error rate ~280-fold lower than that ofTaqDNA Polymerase, Q5 Hot Start High-Fidelity DNA Polymerase is ideal for cloning and can be used for long or difficult amplicons. Q5 Hot Start High-Fidelity DNA Polymerase is supplied with an optimized buffer system that allows robust amplification regardless of GC content. The 5X Q5 Reaction Buffer contains 2 mM Mg++at final (1X) reaction concentrations and is recommended for most routine applications. For GC-rich targets (≥ 65% GC), amplification can be improved by the addition of the 5X Q5 High GC Enhancer. Q5 Hot Start High-Fidelity DNA Polymerase is unlike typical, lower fidelity PCR enzymes. To determine the optimal annealing temperatures for a given set of primers, use of the NEB TmCalculatoris highly recommended.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":2,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":667,"length":2},{"style":"italic","offset":349,"length":3},{"style":"sub","offset":1047,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":1042,"length":16}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"11BFA2CD87F211EAA1D20242AC110006","url":"https://www.neb.com/external-links/tm-calculator"}}}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"70p70","text":"General Guidelines:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1dnp3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"27ons","text":"1. Template:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fpdgr","text":"Use of high quality, purified DNA templates greatly enhances the success of PCR. Recommended amounts of DNA template for a 50 µl reaction are as follows:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"agcmo","text":"DNAAMOUNTDNA Genomic1 ng–1 µgPlasmid or Viral1 pg–1 ng","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":54}],"data":{}},{"key":"3esjr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2mqah","text":"2. Primers:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fb3r1","text":"Oligonucleotide primers are generally 20–40 nucleotides in length and ideally have a GC content of 40–60%. Computer programs such as Primer3 can be used to design or analyze primers. The best results are typically seen when using each primer at a final concentration of 0.5 µM in the reaction. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":133,"length":7}],"data":{}},{"key":"tf5f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"740h0","text":"3. Mg++ and additives:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":5,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fn97g","text":"Mg++ concentration of 2.0 mM is optimal for most PCR products generated with Q5 High-Fidelity DNA Polymerase. When used at a final concentration of 1X, the Q5 Reaction Buffer provides the optimal Mg++ concentration. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":2,"length":2},{"style":"sup","offset":198,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"s5e8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bv90e","text":"Amplification of some difficult targets, like GC-rich sequences, may be improved by the addition of 1X Q5 High GC Enhancer. The Q5 High GC Enhancer is not a buffer and should not be used alone. It should be added only to reactions with the Q5 Reaction Buffer when other conditions have failed. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"do05f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1jpnf","text":"4. Deoxynucleotides: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7l4uj","text":"The final concentration of dNTPs is typically 200 μM of each deoxynucleotide. Q5 Hot Start High-Fidelity DNA Polymerase cannot incorporate dUTP and is not recommended for use with uracil-containing primers or templates. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dd1er","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5b9mt","text":"5. Q5 Hot Start High-Fidelity DNA Polymerase concentration:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a2ot0","text":"We generally recommend using Q5 Hot Start High-Fidelity DNA Polymerase at a final concentration of 20 units/ml (1.0 unit/50 μl reaction). However, the optimal concentration of Q5 Hot Start High-Fidelity DNA Polymerase may vary from 10–40 units/ml (0.5–2 units/50 μl reaction) depending on amplicon length and difficulty. Do not exceed 2 units/50 μl reaction, especially for amplicons longer than 5 kb.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bikh1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"acj9","text":"6. Buffers:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2b6b0","text":"The 5X Q5 Reaction Buffer provided with the enzyme is recommended as the first-choice buffer for robust, high-fidelity amplification. For difficult amplicons, such as GC-rich templates or those with secondary structure, the addition of the Q5 High GC Enhancer can improve reaction performance. The 5X Q5 Reaction Buffer contains 2.0 mM Mg++ at the final (1X) concentration.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":338,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"30t1h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ihmo","text":"7. Denaturation:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fuiu6","text":"Q5 Hot Start High-Fidelity DNA Polymerase does not require a separate activation step.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":86}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bnq9n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4f7tq","text":"An initial denaturation of 30 seconds at 98°C is sufficient for most amplicons from pure DNA templates. Longer denaturation times can be used (up to 3 minutes) for templates that require it. During thermocycling, the denaturation step should be kept to a minimum. Typically, a 5–10 second denaturation at 98°C is recommended for most templates.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"tlk9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fed43","text":"8. Annealing:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d53rh","text":"Optimal annealing temperatures for Q5 Hot Start High-Fidelity DNA Polymerase tend to be higher than for other PCR polymerases. The NEB Tm Calculator should be used to determine the annealing temperature when using this enzyme. Typically, use a 10–30 seconds annealing step at 3°C above the Tm of the lower Tm primer. A temperature gradient can also be used to optimize the annealing temperature for each primer pair.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":136,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":291,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":307,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":131,"length":17}],"data":{}},{"key":"21sqa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3so7l","text":"For high Tm primer pairs, two-step cycling without a separate annealing step can be used (see note 11).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":10,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8it8n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bo2ls","text":"9. Extension:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cqlvc","text":"The recommended extension temperature is 72°C. Extension times are generally 20–30 seconds per kb for complex, genomic samples, but can be reduced to 10 seconds per kb for simple templates (plasmid, E. coli, etc.) or complex templates \u003c 1 kb. Extension time can be increased to 40 seconds per kb for cDNA or long, complex templates, if necessary.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":199,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6kb7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c8lt8","text":"A final extension of 2 minutes at 72°C is recommended.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4njck","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3osjh","text":"10. Cycle number:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2moj6","text":"Generally, 25–35 cycles yield sufficient product.  For genomic amplicons, 30-35 cycles are recommended.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3rc80","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dob5b","text":"11. 2-step PCR:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8q8c1","text":"When primers with annealing temperatures ≥ 72°C are used, a 2-step thermocycling protocol (combining annealing and extension into one step) is possible.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"tmif","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c5qd","text":"12. Amplification of long products:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2cihr","text":"When amplifying products \u003e 6 kb, it is often helpful to increase the extension time to 40–50 seconds/kb.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f95v9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b1pqi","text":"13. PCR product:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8m717","text":"The PCR products generated using Q5 Hot Start High-Fidelity DNA Polymerase have blunt ends. If cloning is the next step, then blunt-end cloning is recommended. If T/A-cloning is preferred, the DNA should be purified prior to A-addition, as Q5 Hot Start High-Fidelity DNA Polymerase will degrade any overhangs generated.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b3ghs","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"48ril","text":"Addition of an untemplated -dA can be done with Taq DNA Polymerase (NEB #M0267) or Klenow exo– (NEB #M0212).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":48,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":68,"length":10},{"key":4,"offset":96,"length":10}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"tables","mutability":"","data":{"cellsMeta":{"A_1":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"B_1":{"className":"_dt-bold"}},"colTitles":["",""],"colWidths":[225,"139"],"data":[["DNA","AMOUNT"],["DNA Genomic","1 ng–1 µg"],["Plasmid or Viral","1 pg–1 ng"]],"guid":"870ED490457F11E9A24D69A8AA1320D3","isJexcelDataFormat":true,"legend":"","mergeCells":{},"printData":[["DNA","AMOUNT"],["DNA Genomic","1 ng–1 µg"],["Plasmid or Viral","1 pg–1 ng"]],"rowHeights":[23,23,23],"show_headers":true}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"72B6EE3B745C4A6EAF4EB55C23057D87","url":"http://bioinfo.ut.ee/primer3/"}},"2":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"466174C969854321BB1817E1FEA048D5","url":"https://tmcalculator.neb.com/#!/main"}},"3":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"A87F1BB1D69144BF911BD01C12050065","url":"https://www.neb.com/products/m0267-taq-dna-polymerase-with-thermopol-buffer"}},"4":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"17374FECCD4A49628BA550210FA4551F","url":"https://www.neb.com/products/m0212-klenow-fragment-3-5-exo"}}}}
keywords: q 5, HiFi, DNA amplification, polymerase chain reaction, PCR with Hot Start HiFi DNA Polymerase

{"blocks":[{"key":"fiehq","text":"Gently mix the reaction. Collect all liquid to the bottom of the tube by a quick spin if necessary and overlay the sample with mineral oil if using a PCR machine without a heated lid. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
